key_points: Colonial Pipeline's scheduling system experience a brief network outage but was back online on Tuesday.
The disruption was due to efforts to harden the system following a cyberattack, not a new infection.
A recent cyberattack led to a week-long outage of the 5,500-mile pipeline, causing significant fuel supply disruptions.
The cyberattack caused widespread fuel shortages, with thousands of U.S. southeast gas stations running dry.
Colonial has been working to normalize fuel deliveries using its shipping nomination system.
The shipping nomination system is managed by a third-party company, Transport4 (T4), which did not comment on the incident.
Despite restoration, the scheduling system was still operating slower than normal.
Over 10,400 filling stations were still without fuel as of Tuesday, improvement from the peak of over 16,000.
Fuel outages in several states including North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia, and Georgia dropped below 50%.
GasBuddy's Patrick De Haan anticipated the number of stations without gasoline to drop under 10,000 by Tuesday.
